Stone, along with grass, is one of the first two blocks in Minecraft.[1] This can be seen by its position in terrain.png and numeric block ID of 1.
The texture of stone is from one of Notch's previous games, RubyDung.
The texture of stone has been changed.
The old texture used for stone is recycled and modified for use by cobblestone.
Creeper explosions no longer destroy stone or stone-like blocks.
A pickaxe is now required to mine stone.
Stone can also be mined by hands other than the pickaxe.
A pickaxe is now required to mine stone once again.
Cobblestone is now smeltable into normal stone.
Mining stone no longer drops cobblestone due to a glitch relating to all entities.
Mining stone now drops cobblestone once again.
As cobblestone can be generated using water and lava, stone has become a renewable resource.
Stone can now be used to craft stone pressure plates (3 stone in slab fashion) and stone buttons (2 stone in the stick shape).
The stone slab recipe now uses 3 stone instead of cobblestone.
The stone pressure plate recipe now requires 2 stone instead of 3.
Stone can now be used to craft redstone repeaters.
Stone can now be crafted into stone bricks.
Stone can now be made by having lava flow on top of water. In previous versions, the lava would replace the water and continue falling.
The texture of stone has been changed slightly.
Stone buttons are now crafted with only one stone.
Stone blocks have been given new sounds for being walked on and mined.
Stone can now be used to craft redstone comparators.
Stone can now be used to craft hoppers.
Stone is no longer used to craft hoppers.
Stone textures are now randomly mirrored and rotated 180 degrees, making large areas of stone look less uniform.
The texture of stone has been changed.
Stone can now be smelted into smooth stone.
The texture of stone has been changed, once again.
Stone can now be found in chests in village mason houses.
Stone can now be used to craft stonecutters.
Stone is now bought by villagers of the new mason profession.
Changed lighting. Now it's match to Bedrock Edition since v0.10.0 build 1.
The default brightness has been changed from "Moody" to 50. Now it's match to Bedrock Edition since alpha 1.1.0.8.
The texture of stone has been changed.
Stone can now be used to craft stone slabs.
Stone can now be used to craft stone bricks.
Changed lighting. Now it's match to Java Edition since rd-20090515.
Changed lighting. It's slightly different from v0.9.0 build 1.
Stone can now be obtained using pickaxes with the Silk Touch enchantment.
Stone can now be used to craft stone buttons and pressure plates.
Stone can now be used to craft redstone repeaters and redstone comparators.
The default brightness has been changed from 0 to 50.
Stone can now be smelted into smooth stone.
Stone is now used to craft stone slabs and stairs.
The texture of stone has been changed.
Stone can now be used to craft grindstones and stonecutters.
Stone mason villagers now buy 20-26 stone as part of their second tier trades.
Stone can now be found in village mason chests.
Trading has been changed, apprentice-level stone mason villagers now buy 20 stone as part of their trades.
Stone is no longer used to repair stone tools and weapons on an Anvil.
The texture of stone has been changed.
The newly-implemented granite, andesite and diorite, as well as the polished versions for each, use stone's ID and are distinguished using metadata.
Stone with numerical metadata variants 7 through 15, which are inaccessible through normal gameplay, now have no model rather than appearing identical to stone.

Stone and its variants are now defined via block states rather than by numerical metadata. Prior to this version, the numerical metadata variants of stone were as follows:
DV Description
0 Stone
1 Granite
2 Polished Granite
3 Diorite
4 Polished Diorite
5 Andesite
6 Polished Andesite
7-15 Inaccessible "boring" variants of stone
Stone with metadata values 7 through 15 have now been completely removed from the game.
The different block states for the stone ID have been split up into their own IDs.
Prior to The Flattening, this block's numeral ID was 1.

texts.text: Stone is a block found underground in the Overworld or on the surface of mountains.

Stone requires a pickaxe to be mined, in which case it drops cobblestone. When mined without a pickaxe, it drops nothing. If a stone is mined with a Silk Touch enchanted pickaxe, it drops itself.
Times are for unenchanted tools as wielded by players with no status effects, measured in seconds. For more information, see Breaking § Speed.

Stone makes up the majority of the solid blocks generated in the Overworld above y=0. From y=8 downwards, stone gradually transitions into deepslate, until it is completely replaced by deepslate at and below y=0.

When chunks generate, stone can be found under 1-5 layers of grass blocks, dirt, gravel, clay, coarse dirt, podzol, mycelium, sand, sandstone, red sand, red sandstone or terracotta, depending on the biome.
When the world is generating new chunks, some stone is replaced with blobs of other blocks. They may also be revealed on the side of small hills.
Stone also generates in igloo basements and some Overworld ruined portals.
Stone also makes up most of the blocks on the void start platform, in Superflat worlds created with the Void biome preset.‌[Java Edition only]
Main article: Tutorials/Cobblestone farming § Stone generation
Stone can also be made by lava flowing on top of water blocks (both flowing and source). The water is replaced by stone.
Stone can be smelted from cobblestone.
Silverfish can enter and hide in stone, creating an infested block.
Apprentice-level stone mason villagers offer to buy 20 stone for an emerald.
Stone can be placed under note blocks to produce "bass drum" sounds.
ID of block's direct item form, which is used in savegame files and addons.
The block's direct item form has the same id with the block.
Issues relating to "Stone" are maintained on the bug tracker. Report issues there.
